Earned millions on Crimea last year
Several publishing managers and authors increased their income significantly last year.
05 Nov 2019, 17:32 by Caroline Enge
Crimea books sell, and this is reflected in the author's income. Among the best-selling authors last year, as usual, Jo Nesb√∏ made the most of almost NOK 42 million. Several of the best-sellers doubled their revenues from the previous year (see the table below).
- The vast majority of writers are struggling to sell enough books to make a living. One is usually dependent on other jobs or scholarships. It is therefore a privilege to be able to sell well, says crime writer Tom Egeland.
Egeland is among those who announced the transition to the newly formed Capitana publishing company last year. The sheer focus on crime and suspense has proved profitable, for publishers and writers alike.
Capitana author J√∏rgen J√¶ger earned $ 2.9 million in 2018.
- Capitana is progressive and dares to think new. Instead of spending a lot, they do a lot with the few books they focus on, says J√¶ger.

Lucrative Crimean publishing house
Jonas Forsang and Magnus R√∏nningen started Fym publishing company in 2015 which became Capitana in 2018 when Petter Stordalen entered with NOK 20 million. According to the tax lists, Forsang earned NOK 2.1 million in 2018, but emphasizes that they have not yet taken out dividends from Capitana. However, he has made money on the books about Petter Northug and Gunnhild Stordalen, which is published by sister publisher Pilar (also owned by Strawberry publishing).
- I love getting to work with so many interesting people who are in the book industry. We believe that the need for stories is only getting bigger, says Forsang.


J√∏rn Lier Horst broke last year with Gyldendal. He now owns 25 percent of the publisher Capitana.üì∑ Siri √òverland Eriksen

Capitana has a total of eight Norwegian authors. Among them is co-owner of Capitana J√∏rn Lier Horst, who also has two books on the bestseller list for 2018. He ended up with an income of NOK 22.3 million last year, more than twice as much as in 2017.
Among the other Capitana writers who earned more than the million last year are J√∏rgen J√¶ger (2.9 million), Thomas Enger (1.1 million), Knut N√¶rum (1.1 million) and Tom Egeland (2.8 million) .
Read more about the publishing economy here:
Several bestsellers doubled their income
The median income among authors is only NOK 120,000 in Norway. But for those who end up on the bestseller lists, the equation looks quite different. Among the best-selling Norwegian authors last year, several of them have doubled their income from the previous year. Among them is Maja Lunde, who earned DKK 10.9 million in 2018.


Unni Lindell's "Dronen" became the 17th best-selling book in Norway last year. Together, the author earned over 2 million kroner.üì∑ Olav Hegg√∏

Lars Mytting, who is also popular abroad, earned NOK 3.5 million last year. This is an increase of 2.7 million from the previous year.
Crimean queen Unni Lindell also increased her income by one million, to NOK 2, 1 million in 2018.

Vigmostad earned 10 million
Despite the fact that some authors earn large sums on the books, the publishing industry has struggled in recent years. Both Cappelen Damm and Aschehoug made huge deficits last year.
The tax records show that Cappelen Damm's CEO Tom Harald Jenssen lost nearly NOK 700,000 in income and earned 4.4 million in 2018. Aschehougs Mads Nygaard, for his part, earned NOK 2.8 million, roughly the same as the year before.
Among the large Norwegian publishing houses went Gyldendal and Vigmostad & Bj√∏rke with profits. According to tax figures, Arno Vigmostad's publisher increased his income by two million to a total of NOK 10.2 million in 2018.
